Package com.rb.nonbiz.util

Class RBOrderingPreconditions

java.lang.Object
com.rb.nonbiz.util.RBOrderingPreconditions
public class RBOrderingPreconditions
extends java.lang.Object
Various static precondition methods (i.e. methods that are expected to throw an exception if their arguments are not deemed valid), pertaining to ordering of items (e.g. 'all must be increasing', etc.)

  • Constructor Summary

    • checkIncreasing

      public static <T> void checkIncreasing​(java.lang.Iterable<T> iterable, java.util.Comparator<T> comparator)
      For n items, throw if the items aren't strictly increasing. If T implements Comparator, it's better to use the overload that doesn't take in a comparator.

      public static void checkDoublesNotIncreasing​(java.lang.Iterable<java.lang.Double> iterable, Epsilon epsilon)
      For n doubles, this expects every consecutive pair of numbers to decrease, or stay the same, or increase only by an epsilon amount. It will throw otherwise.

    • checkDecreasingPerPartialComparison

      public static <T> void checkDecreasingPerPartialComparison​(PartialComparator<T> partialComparator, java.util.List<T> list, java.lang.String format, java.lang.Object... args)
      For n items, throw if the items are not decreasing, in the 'partial comparison' sense. Since we are dealing with a partial ordering, it is possible that e.g. a < b, c < d, but there are no other partial orderings. Therefore, we must check all pairs, not just consecutive ones, as we would with 'non-partial' comparisons. For example, dacb is invalid because a > b and d > c, but bc and ca aren't invalid, as no partial comparison exists for those.

    • checkDecreasingPerPartialComparison

      public static <T extends PartiallyComparable<T>> void checkDecreasingPerPartialComparison​(java.util.List<T> list, java.lang.String format, java.lang.Object... args)
      For n items, throw if the items are not decreasing, in the 'partial comparison' sense. Since we are dealing with a partial ordering, it is possible that e.g. a < b, c < d, but there are no other partial orderings. Therefore, we must check all pairs, not just consecutive ones, as we would with 'non-partial' comparisons. For example, dacb is invalid because a > b and d > c, but bc and ca aren't invalid, as no partial comparison exists for those.

    • checkConsecutiveClosedDoubleRanges

      public static <T> void checkConsecutiveClosedDoubleRanges​(java.util.Iterator<ClosedRange<java.lang.Double>> rangesIterator, Epsilon epsilon)
      This checks that the right endpoint of a subrange is the left endpoint of the next subrange, e.g. {[x0, x1], [x1, x2], [x2, x3]} We often model a closed range as a partition of connected subranges that make up the entire range. We actually model this with closed ranges. It would have been more correct to use open ranges on one side of each 'connection point', such as { [x0, x1), [x1, x2), [x2, x3]}, but this is a bit less relevant for doubles, since we never care about precise equality anyway. Used closed ranges everywhere is more expedient.
